intro: Malveopsis coulteri, commonly known as Coulter's mallow, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It belongs to the Malvaceae family, which includes hibiscus and cotton, and is characterized by its showy, five-petaled flowers. The plant typically grows in dry, rocky habitats and has hairy, glandular leaves that help reduce water loss. Its flowers are usually pink to purple in color and bloom in late spring to early summer. Malveopsis coulteri is often found in chaparral and woodland areas, where it contributes to local biodiversity.
